questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in all of the following except
questions.solution:
The inherited causes of Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia are: 

  • Criggler Najjar syndrome 
  • Gilbert’s syndrome  

 UGC -   Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia              

            Gilbert's syndrome              

            Criggler Najjar syndrome 

Breast milk jaundice- Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia 

  • Breast milk contains glucuronidase enzyme that deconjugates the conjugated bilirubin.  
  • Hence it will cause Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

 

The causes of Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia include:

  • Hemolytic disorders-
    • Inherited- Spherocytosis, Sickle cell anemia, G6PD deficiency
    • Acquired-  PNH, Malaria, Babesiosis
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis-
    • Vit B12
    • Folic acid and Iron deficiencies
    • Thalassemias
  • Increased bilirubin production-
    • Massive blood transfusion
    • Large hematoma
  • Drugs-
    • Ribavirin
    • Rifampicin
    • Probenecid
    • Novobiocin
  • Inherited conditions-
    • Gilberts syndrome
    • Crigler Najjar syndrome
  • Breast milk jaundice-
    • Glucuronidase enzyme
  • Physiological jaundice of new born-
    • Decreased UGTA activity

questions.text: The mineral which potentiates the action of Insulin
questions.solution:
Chromium potentiates the action of insulin in patients with impaired glucose tolerance, presumably by increasing insulin receptor-mediated signaling, although its usefulness in treating type 2 diabetes is uncertain.

Rich food sources of chromium include:

  • yeast,
  • meat,
  • grain products

Chromium in the trivalent state is largely nontoxic however, chromium-6 is a known pulmonary carcinogen as well as a cause of liver, kidney, and CNS damage.

questions.text: Which antibody is positive in drug induced lupus
questions.solution:
Anti histone antibody is mainly positive (70 %) in drug induced lupus.

Option A : Anti-dsDNA -   High titers are SLE-specific and in some patients correlate with disease activity, nephritis, vasculitis.

Option C : Anti-Sm  -  Specific for SLE, no definite clinical correlations, most patients also have anti- RNP, more common in Blacks and Asians

Option D : Antinuclear antibodies - Best screening test for SLE.

questions.text: Drug of choice for the prevention of acute mountain sickness
questions.solution:
Acetazolamide is the drug of choice for acute mountain sickness prevention.

Acetazolamide inhibits renal carbonic anhydrase, causing prompt bicarbonate diuresis, that leads to metabolic acidosis and hyperventilation. Acetazolamide (125–250 mg twice a day), administered for 1 day before ascent and continued for 2 or 3 days is effective.

Paresthesia and a tingling sensation are common side effects of acetazolamide.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in Sarcoidosis
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia and/or hypercalciuria occurs in about 10% of sarcoidosis patients.

Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas. The disease is often multi system and requires the presence of involvement in two or more organs for a specific diagnosis.

The mechanism of abnormal calcium metabolism leading to hypercalcemia with a suppressed parathyroid hormone (PTH) level is shown below.

 

Hypercalcemia is the most likely cause of sarcoidosis associated acute renal failure in 1-2% of sarcoidosis patients.

questions.text: Which among the following is a small vessel vasculitis
questions.solution:
• Large vessel vasculitis – Takayasu arteritis and Giant cell arteritis 
  • Medium vessel vasculitis-  Poyartiritis nodosa and Kawasaki disease  
  • Small vessel vasculitis- 
    •  ANCA positive:  
      • Microscopic polyangitis 
      • Wegner’s Granulomatosis   
      • Churg-strauss syndrome 
    •   ANCA Negative: 
      • Hench schonlein purpura 
      • Essential cryoglobulinuria

questions.text: All are features of Wilsons disease except
questions.solution:
• Coombs negative Hemolytic anemia, Dystonia, Chronic active hepatitis are features of Wilson’s disease.
  • Testicular atrophy is not seen Wilson’s disease.

Wilson’s disease:

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • The gene affected is localized on Chromosome 13.
  • The disease is characterized by the defect in the copper transporting adenine tri-phosphatase in the liver affecting biliary copper excretion leading to excessive accumulation of copper in liver and brain.

Features:

  • Hepatic involvement:  Acute/ Fulminant/ Chronic active hepatitis/ Cirrhosis.
  • Neurological features: Dystonia, In-coordination, Tremor.
  • Autonomic Disturbance may occur.
  • Pathognomic sign: Keyser- Fleischer ring.
  • Hemolytic anemia.
  • Portal hypertension.
  • Renal calculi.
  • Cholelithiasis, Hypersplenism.
  • Aminoaciduria, Microscopic hematuria.
  • Renal tubular acidosis, Hyperparathyroidism, Infertility.

Features not seen:

  • Sensory neuropathy.
  • Myopathy.
  • Hepatoma.
  • Testicular atrophy.

Hypogonadism is a feature of Hemochromatosis.

questions.text: Basket weave appearance of Glomerular basement membrane on electron transport microscopy is seen in
questions.solution:
Basket-weave appearance of glomerular basement membrane is seen in Alport's Syndrome.

Image: Electron micrograph from kidney biopsy demonstrating characteristic findings of Alport’s carrier state. The glomerular basement membranes have variable segmental lamination, creating a “basket weave” appearance and there is segmental foot process effacement with microvillus transformation.

Alport syndrome is a group of inherited heterogenous disorders caused by mutations in Type 4 collagen chain on chromosome Xq22-24.

It manifests by:

  • hematuria with progression to chronic renal failure.
  • accompanied by nerve deafness.
  • various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.

The 3 genetic types of Alport syndromes are:

  • X linked Alport Syndrome (XLAS)most common form (80-85%cases)
  • Autosomal Recessive Alport Syndrome(ARAS) 15% of cases
  • Autosomal Dominant Alport Syndrome(ADAS) 5% cases

Alport's patients typically have thin basement membranes on renal biopsy, which thicken over time into multi-lamellations surrounding lucent areas that often contain granules of varying density resulting in the so-called split basement membrane or basket weave appearance.

questions.text: Which among the following is not included in criteria for diagnosis of Kawasaki Disease
questions.solution:
Cardiac involvement- Kawasaki’s disease is the most common cause of acquired heart disease in children. But its not in criteria.

 

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival infection (90% of cases)

questions.text: In a patient only Anti HBsAg is positive in serum, all other viral markers are negative, this indicates

choices.text: Immunized person with hepatitis B vaccine

questions.solution:
Immunized person with hepatitis B vaccine.

Serology of Hepatitis:

Vaccinated cases have only Anti HBs antibody in their serum

  • Both patient with acute and chronic hepatitis have HBsAg positive serology, the differentiating feature being the Anti HBc which will be IgM in acute and IgG in chronic hepatitis B. 
  • Immunized individuals who never had any prior exposure will have only Anti HBs antibody. 
  • Window period is the period between the disappearance of HBsAg and appearance of Anti HBs,  only Anti HBc antibody of type IgM will be positive. 
  • HBe Ag and HBV DNA indicate infectivity of the affected individual, and will be positive in only in infective cases. 
  • Recovered/cured cases of Hep B will have IgG Anti HBc antibody , with recently recovered cases having added positivity for Anti HBs antibody. 
  • Patients in the low or nonreplicating phase/inactive carrier state are HBeAg negative and anti-HBe positive
  • Both coinfection and super infection of HBV with HDV will be positive for HBsAg and Anti HDV. 
  • Acute Hep B with Hep D – Coinfection 
  • Chronic Hep B with recent Hep D - Superinfection
  HBsAg Anti HBs HBe Ag Anti HDV Anti HBc
Acute HBV (infective) +   +   IbM

Acute HBV 

Recovered

   +     IgG
Chronic HBV +   +   IgG
Window period − − −   IgM
False positive/ Very old cured case         IgG
Vaccinated/Immunized   +      
Acute HBV with HDV Co-Infection          
Chronic HBV with HDV super-infection          
 Hbe Ag and HBV DNA indicates infectivity, it will be negetive in serology of non infective cases.

questions.text: Which antibody is incriminated in causing Henoch Scholein Purpura
questions.solution:
Deposits of IgA is characteristic in HSP.  

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a systemic hypersensitivity disease characterized by  

  • palpable purpura.,  
  • colicky abdominal pain, 
  • polyarthralgia, 
  • acute glomerulonephritis.  

All these changes result from deposition of immune complexes with IgA on the endothelium of vessels throughout the body. 

It is the most common systemic vasculitis in children.

It is a subtype of acute leukocytoclastic vasculitis (LCV) or cutaneous small vessel vasculitis.

Renal disease is of particular concern in adults with HSP. 

Antinuclear antibodies in HSP 

HSP patients are usually negative for  

  • Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) 
  • Antibodies to nuclear cytoplasmic antigen (ANCA) 
  • Rheumatoid factor (even in presence of Rheumatoid nodules)  

 Mneumonic for Henoch Schonlein PurpurA:

 H- Hematuria 

 S- Spots on buttocks, leg, feet of small children

 P- Purpura

 A-IgA immune complex deposition   

Direct immunofluorescence examination shows deposits of IgA within dermal blood vessel walls.

questions.text: The image given below is the cut section  stomach of a patient with Menetrier’s disease. True about this condition
questions.solution:
The image given above represents Menetrier’s disease.

Menetrier’s disease:

  • It is a rare gastropathy characterized by large, tortuous mucosal folds.
  • It is predominant in 40-60 years male.
  • Site – Body and fundus, Antrum is spared.
  • Etiology in children- CMV.
  • Pathogenesis – Over expression of TGF-α leading to foveolar hyperplasia.
  • Features include  Protein losing enteropathy and Edema.
  • Diagnosis is done by  Endoscopy with deep muscle biopsy. 
  • Cetuximab is now considered as the first line of treatment for Menetrier’s disease( Cetuximab is a monoclonal antibody which inhibitor of EGFR receptor that is also used in the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer, metastatic non- small cell lung cancer and head and neck cancer.) 
  • Other drugs used are Anticholinergic agents, Prostaglandins,PPI, Octreotide, Prednisone.

questions.text: Most common cause of death in Cancer
questions.solution:
• The most common causes of death in patients with cancer are infection leading to circulatory failure, respiratory failure, hepatic and renal failure.
  • Intestinal blockage may lead to starvation and inanition.

questions.text: The presence of OmpC antibody is a surrogate marker of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
• Anti-OmpC (anti-outer membrane protein citrullinated antibody) is a serological surrogate marker of Crohn’s disease.
  • Also seen in healthy family members of patients with Crohn's disease
  • p-ANCA and ASCA are the two most important serological markers for Inflammatory Bowel disease.
  • ASCA is also positive in Behcet’s syndrome.
Disease ASCA positivity p-ANCA positivity
Crohn's disease 70% 5-10%
Ulcerative colitis 10-15% 60-70%

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in behcets syndrome
questions.solution:
Behcet syndrome 

  • Option B-Oral ulcer- apthous ulcer (can b deep) –Essential Criteria 
  • Option C- Genital ulcer- painful 
  • Option D- Ocular involvement- scarring can cause b/l pan uveitis 

Reactive arthritis Classical triad 

  • Arthritis 
  • Urethritis 
  • Conjunctivitis   

Also associated 

  • Oral ulcers(always superficial) 
  • Genital lesion- circinate balanitis- painless

questions.text: Joint not involved in osteoarthritis is
questions.solution:
Important joints of hand involved 

  • RA – PIP, MCP, Wrist  
  • OA- DIP, PIP, 1st CMC  
  • Psoriatic arthritis - DIP, PIP  
  • Pseudogout- MCP, Wrist

questions.text: Tegaserod is
questions.solution:
Tegaserod-

Selective 5-HT4 partial agonist.

The stimulated enteric neurons stimulate

  • proximal bowel contraction (via acetylcholine and substance P).
  • distal bowel relaxation (via nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal peptide).

It is used for irritable bowel syndrome with constipation.

S/E: Increased incidence of cardiovascular problems. 

Cisapride, a 5-HT 4 agonist, was used in the treatment of gastroesophageal reflux and motility disorders  causes QTc prolongation.

questions.text: Which of the following presents with hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea presents with hypokalemia + metabolic acidosis.

Diarrhoea causes non anion gap gastrointestinal bicarbonate, resulting In metabolic acidosis and the loss of potassium resulting in hypokalemia.

Other options:

  • Option b: vomiting results in hypokalemia + metabolic alkalosis
  • Option c: nasogastric suction results in hypokalemia + metabolic alkalosis
  • Option d: conn's syndrome (primary aldosteronism) results in hypokalemia + metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Most common type of Multiple Sclerosis
questions.solution:
The most common type of MS is the relapsing type [RMS] (~90%)

About 2% of RMS progresses to secondary progressive MS [SPMS] and about 10% develop the type of primary progressive MS [PPMS]

Note: SPMS or even PPMS will occasionally experience relapses and remissions, although far less often than in RMS. The term progression is now reserved to describe neurological worsening that accumulates independently from disease activity.

questions.text: A 40 year old women presented to you with cough, conductive deafness and hematuria. Her investigations revealed proteinuria and the following CT picture. What is your diagnosis
questions.solution:
Wegner’s granulomatosis

 Necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels involving  

  • URT: - Serous otitis media- Conductive deafness ( From question- cough and conductive deafness) 
  • LRT: - Lung- B/L infiltrative lesions (From Image in Q)  
  • Kidney:- Glomerulonephritis – Proteinuria, hematuria 
  • Other manifestations can also be present like – conjunctivitis, fever

questions.text: Most common CNS manifestation of Whipple’s disease is
questions.solution:
Cognitive changes profressing to dementia is the most common CNS manifestation of Whipple’s disease.

Whipple’s disease:

  • It is a multi-system disease caused by Tropheryma whipplei.
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy of the small intestine.
  • Histopathology – PAS-positive macrophages that contain gram-positive bacilli.
  • Treatment – Double strength Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 1 year.
  • 2nd line of choice – Chloramphenicol.

questions.text: Transformation of CLL/SLL to DLBCL is called
questions.solution:
Richter's syndrome or Richter's transformation involves transformation of CLL/SLL to DLBCL.

Richter's transformation was first described as development of an aggressive large cell lymphoma in the setting of a small lymphocytic lymphoma/ chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL/SLL).

RT should be suspected in patients with CLL/SLL who develop:

  • Rapidly progressive lymphadenopathy
  • Extranodal sites of disease
  • Systemic symptoms
  • Elevated levels of serum LDH

Diagnosis of RT is done after a biopsy, and it usually shows histological pattern consistent with DLBCL.

questions.text: Anticoagulant of choice for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
questions.solution:
Lepirudin is the anticoagulant of choice for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

In Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT), there is the formation of IgG antibodies against heparin platelet factor 4 complexes which activates them, resulting in a prothrombotic state even in the presence of thrombocytopenia.

HIT usually occurs 5-10 days after exposure to heparins.

Management of HIT:

  • Stop all forms of heparin, LMW Heparin
  • Direct thrombin inhibitors (Lepirudin, Argatroban) are anticoagulants of choice
  • Lepirudin is safe in Liver failure, Argatroban is safe in Renal failure
  • Lepirudin is continued till platelet count is 100000/microLitre
  • Warfarin is started and direct thrombin inhibitors are discontinued

questions.text: Acute Lung Injury (ALI) is characterized by all, except?
questions.solution:
In ALI, PCWP will be < 18 mmHg.

Acute Lung Injury is a milder disorder than ARDS but it can evolve eventually into ARDS.

Diagnostic Criteria ALI ARDS
PiO2/FiO2(Carrico index) ≤300mm Hg ≤200mm Hg
Onset Acute Acute
Chest XRay B/L alveolar/interstitial infiltrates B/L alveolar/interstitial infiltrates
Absence of left atrial hypertension

PCWP≤18 mmHg

No clinical evidence of increased left atrial pressure

PCWP≤18 mmHg

No clinical evidence of increased left atrial pressure

questions.text: 32 year old AIDS positive female presented with headaches and nuchal stiffness. On LP examination clear CSF was obtained with leukocytes more than 100/cu.mm. India ink staining was positive. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Features of meningitis with India Ink Staining positive like in the above case is highly suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis.

Cryptococcal meningitis is common in Immunocompromised patients.

It results from hematogenous spread from lungs which is usually the primary site.

 

 

There are 3 dominant CNS forms of the disease:

  • Meningitis
  • Cryptococcosis
  • Gelatinous pseudocyst

 

 

 

 

Treatment:

  • I.V Amphotericin
  • Flucytosine

questions.text: Not seen with Vitamin C toxicity
questions.solution:
Clinical features of Vitamin C toxicity:

  • Abdominal pain, diarrhoea, nausea
  • Increased prevalence of kidney stones (oxalate)
  • Iron overload (in patients on supplement iron)
  • Hemolysis (G6PD deficiency)

questions.text: All are features of Hypernatremia except
questions.solution:
Clinical features of Hypernatremia:

  • Dehydration resulting in doughy skin
  • CNS symptoms like irritability, restlessness, lethargy
  • High pitched cry, hyperpnoea
  •  Convulsions

questions.text: Most common heavy chain disease
questions.solution:
• Most common heavy chain disease is alpha chain disease called seligmann disease.
  • The heavy chain diseases (HCDs) are rare B cell proliferative disorders characterized by the production of a monoclonal (M) protein consisting of a portion of the immunoglobulin heavy chain without a bound light chain.
  • Alpha HCD is a form of Mucosa Associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT) lymphoma that is also called Immuno Proliferative Small Intestinal Disease (IPSID), Mediterranean lymphoma, or Seligmann disease.

questions.text: Diffusion capacity of Carbon monoxide is elevated in all except:
questions.solution:
DLCO decreases in pulmonary hypertension.

  • The test is performed by using a small and safe amount of carbon monoxide (CO) and measuring the gas exchange which occurs across the alveolar membrane during a 10-sec breath hold (single breath).
  • CO in exhaled breath is analyzed to determine the quantity of CO crossing the alveolar membrane and combining with hemoglobin in red blood cells.

The “single-breath diffusing capacity” (Dlco) value

  • Increases with the surface area available for diffusion and the amount of hemoglobin within the capillaries.
  • Varies inversely with alveolar membrane thickness.

The table below shows the conditions associated with decreased or increased DLCO and the mechanism of the disease:

DLCO decreases DLCO increases
  • Thicken or destroy alveolar membranes (pulmonary fibrosis, emphysema)
  • Curtail the pulmonary vasculature (pulmonary hypertension)
  • Reduce alveolar capillary hemoglobin (anemia)
  • Drugs (Amiodarone, Bleomycin, Methotrexate)
  • Interstitial Lung Disease
  • Acute Congestive Heart Failure
  • Asthma
  • Polycythemia
  • Pulmonary Hemorrhage

questions.text: All are true about hyperthyroidism except
questions.solution:
Weight gain is not a feature of hyperthyroidism.

Effect of thyroid hormone Hyperthyroidism Hypothyroidism
Basal metabolic rate Heat intolerance, Weight loss Cold intolerance
  Weight gain
Fat metabolism Decrease in cholesterol, triglycerides, phospholipids Increase in cholesterol, triglycerids, phospholipids
CVS High systolic BP, Sinus Tachycardia High Diastolic BP
  Bradycardia
GIT Diarrhea Constipation
Muscular system Proximal muscle weakness Distal muscle weakness
Sleep Extreme fatigability but inability to sleep Extreme somnolence with sleeping upto to 12-14 hours.

questions.text: Shelf life of platelets in blood bank is
questions.solution: Platelets are routinely stored in plasma for 5 days at an average temperature of 22°C.

questions.text: Find the incorrect match of PFT value in the following regarding emphysema
questions.solution:
Compliance is increased in cases of emphysema as opposed to the other obstructive diseases.

PFT values in Emphysema:

Loss of lung elastic recoil- Hyperinflation leads to.

  • TLC-Increased.
  • RV-Increased.
  • FRC-Increased.
  • Severe elevation of RV leads to FVC-Decreased.
  • Loss of lung elastic recoil reduces the pressure driving maximal expiratory flow leads to.
  • FEV1- Decreased.
  • FEV1/FVC-Decreased.
  • DLCO- Decreased.
  • Compliance = Change in volume / Change in pressure.
  • Emphysema – compliance is increased(mainly static compliance is increased).

questions.text: An elderly male has inflammation of metatarso-phalangeal joint of 1st  toe.  Aspiration of synovial contents on polarized light microscopy demonstrated
questions.solution:
The given case is highly suggestive of Gout and in the study of synovial aspirate on polarized light, the crystals appear as Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals.

Crystals on Polarised Microscopy
Gout Pseudogout
Negatively Birefringent Positviely birefringent
Needle Shaped Rhomboid crystals
Na Urate(Sodium Urate) Ca pyrophosphate

questions.text: Causes of primary Hyperparathyroidism are all except
questions.solution:
Chronic Renal Failure does not cause primary hyperparathyroidism.

Hyperparathyroidism is of 2 types:

-  Primary hyperparathyroidism: increased parathyroid hormone secretion due to intrinsic abnormality of 1/more parathyroid glands.

  • Single adenoma
  • Multiple adenoma
  • Diffuse hyperplasia
  • Carcinoma

- Secondary hyperparathyroidism: increased parathyroid hormone secretion due to low serum calcium.

  • Chronic renal failure
  • Malabsorption syndrome
  • Vitamin D deficiency
  • Medullary Carcinoma thyroid

questions.text: All are true about diabetes Insipidus except

choices.text: Water deprivation test is used for diagnosis

questions.solution:
There is no dilutional hyponatremia in diabetes insipidus.

In diabetes insipidus, there is low levels of ADH, resulting in excessive water loss from the kidney resulting in hypertonic plasma associated with dilute urine.

It can be:

  • Central diabetes insipidus: impaired secretion of ADH from the pituitary
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus: renal insensitivity to nonresponsiveness to ADH

In both circumstances, serum osmolality is increased and there is low urine osmolality  

Dehydration test is used to differentiate between types of Diabetes Insipidus.

questions.text: Arsenic poisoning causes
questions.solution:
Arsenic is a heavy metal causing a toxic sensorimotor polyneuropathy. It mimics GBS.

Characteristics Demyelinating Axonal Neuronal
Pattern Promixal=distal Distal more than proximal No length dependent
Onset Acute/subacute Slow evolution Rapid
Symptoms Paresthesia, weakness Dysesthesia, weakness Paresthesia, gait ataxia
Motor Distal and proximal weakness Distal weakness Proprioceptive weakness
Nerve biopsy Demylation and remylation Axonal degeneration and regeneration Axonal degeneration but no regeneration
Prognosis Rapid recovery Slow recovery Poor recovery
Causes GBS, Diptheria, CIDP, Diabetes Mellitus, Multifocal motor neuropathy Toxic, Metabolic, HIV, Charcoat tooth disease, Diabetes Mellitus Srojen,s cisplatin pyridoxine

questions.text: A patient presents with weight loss, fever, and nocturnal cough. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy are noted. Serology revealed elevated levels of IgE and is positive for anti-filarial antibodies. All of the following are true regarding this condition except:

choices.text: Restrictive changes in pulmonary function tests
Micro filaria seen in peripheral blood

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with serology showing high levels of IgE and anti-filarial antibodies is suggestive of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia. All are true regarding this condition except the presence of microfilaria in the blood. 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is a syndrome due to filarial infection. It occurs when the microfilaria released from the lymphatics get trapped in the lungs. These parasites then elicit inflammatory response in the pulmonary tissue. This syndrome is characterized by nocturnal paroxysmal wheeze and cough (option B), weight loss, low-grade fever, and lymphadenopathy.

The microfilariae are not usually found in the peripheral blood as they get rapidly sequestrated in the lungs and are cleared from the bloodstream.

Investigations show eosinophilia >3000/μL, chest radiographs show mottled opacities and increased broncho vascular markings, and pulmonary function tests show restrictive changes in most cases and obstructive changes in a few cases.(option C).

Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) for 14 days is useful in treating the condition (option A).

questions.text: All are correct about SIADH except

choices.text: Normal BP with gain of water

questions.solution:
Relative Hypernatremia is not a feature of SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate AntiDiuretic Hormone secretion).

Clinical features of SIADH 

  • Hyponatremia (Na less than 135mEq/L)
  • Inappropriately elevated urine osmolality (less than 150mosm/Kg)
  • Excessive urine sodium excretion (more than 30 mEq/L) 
  • Decreased serum osmolality (less than280mosm/Kg)

Laboratory features

  • Hyponatremia (Na less than 135 mEq/L) 
  • B.U.N. and serum uric acid falls because of plasma dilution and increased excretoin of nitrogenous products
  • Serum potassium and bicarbonate levels are normal in SIADH 
  • Low serum osmolality

questions.text: Most common infection in patients with prosthetic valves:
questions.solution:
Staphylococci and streptococci can account for majority of Infective endocarditis. 

  • Staphylococcal infective endocarditis is more common in healthcare associated infective endocarditis cases and it accounts for more than half of infective endocarditis cases.
  • Streptococci remains common cause of community acquired infective endocarditis.
  • Injection drug use endocarditis is more common in young males and it affects the right side of the heart. 
  • The tricuspid valve is involved more commonly than the pulmonary valve.

questions.text: Apheresis is

choices.text: Selective separation of components of blood

questions.solution:
Apheresis is the selective separation of blood components.

It is the general technique of extracorporeal blood purification whereby one constituent is removed (centrifugation or filtration)and the remainder is returned to the patient.

 

Cytapheresis is the removal of cellular components from blood. In plasmapheresis, plasma is removed

Blood donation

  • Most common type of donation where whole blood is given
  • Blood is separated into transfusable components – red cells, platelets, plasma and/or cryoprecipitated AHF
  • A person is eligible to donate every 56 days

Platelet apheresis

  • Apheresis machine will collect platelets and some plasma and return the red cells and most of the plasma back to the donor.
  • A single donation of platelets collected by apheresis can constitute 1/ several transfusable units, while it takes 4-6 whole blood donation to constitute a single transfusable unit of platelets.

Plasma apheresis 

  • The apheresis machine will collect plasma and return red cells and platelets back to the donor.  
  • Donors with AB blood group can only give red cells to other type AB recipients. They are the universal plasma reciever.

questions.text: All of the following are the features of Pulmonary Alveolar proteinosis, except _______
questions.solution:
LDH level is elevated in PAP.

Pulmonary Alveolar proteinosis:

  • PAP is an autoimmune disease with a neutralizing antibody of immunoglobulin G isotype against granulocyte-macrophage colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF).
  • Thus neutralization of GM-CSF bioactivity by the antibody causes dysfunction of alveolar macrophages, which results in reduced surfactant clearance.

Pathogenesis: Impaired ability to clear surfactant.

3 different classes of PAP are seen:

  • Acquired (MC).
  • Congenital- Auto-somal recessive transmission with frame shift mutation of SP-B gene.
  • Secondary- Rare in adults.

Caused by:

  • Lysinuric protein intolerance.
  • Acute silicosis.
  • Inhalational syndromes.
  • Immunodeficiency syndromes.
  • Hematopoietic malignancies.

Features:

  • Progressive exertional dyspnoea.
  • Fatigue.
  • Weight loss.
  • Low grade fever.
  • Non productive cough.

Lab findings:

  • Polycythemia.
  • Hypergammaglobulinemia.
  • Increased LDH.
  • Elevated serum levels of Lung surfactant proteins A and D.
  • Elevated Anti GM-CSF titre is seen in serum and BAL fluid.

Radiological findings:

  • Chest X-ray: B/L symmetric alveolar opacities in middle and lower lung zones- Bat wing distribution.
  • HRCT: Ground glass opacification and thickened intra lobular structures.

Special features:

  • PAS positive amorphous lipo-proteinaceous accumulation in distal air spaces.
  • Preservation of underlying architecture of lung.

Treatment :

Whole lung lavage through a double lumen endotracheal tube.

questions.text: Tall and tented T waves, wide QRS and Absent P wave are features of
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia produces a sequence of changes usually beginning with narrowing and peaking (tenting) of the T waves. Further elevation of extracellular K+ leads to:

  • AV conduction disturbances.
  • Diminution in P-wave amplitude.
  • Widening of the QRS interval.

Severe hyperkalemia eventually causes cardiac arrest with a slow sinusoidal type of mechanism("sine-wave" pattern) followed by asystole.

questions.text: To prevent osmotic demyelination syndrome, sodium correction can be done upto:
questions.solution:
• Normal plasma sodium = 136 – 146 mEq/L (mmol/L)
  • Hyponatremia is less than 135 mmol/L
  • Rapid correction of hyponatremia by more than 8-10 mmol in 24 hours or 18 mmol in 48 hours results in slow development of osmotic demyelination syndrome. It was previously called Central Pontine Myelinolysis which classically affected the pons.

questions.text: A 76 year old male comes with a history of frequent falls and difficulty in looking downwards and laterally. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Progressive supranuclear palsy has a characteristic impairment of downward gaze.

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a form of atypical parkinsonism that is characterized by slow ocular saccades, eyelid apraxia, and restricted eye movements with particular impairment of downward gaze. Patients frequently experience hyperextension of the neck with early gait disturbance and frequent falls.

In later stages, speech and swallowing difficulty and cognitive impairment become evident.

MRI may reveal a characteristic atrophy of the midbrain with relative preservation of the pons, the "hummingbird sign" on midsagittal images.

questions.text: Features of tumour lysis syndrome are all except:
questions.solution:
Tumour lysis syndrome does not include hypercalcemia.

Tumour lysis syndrome occurs during the destruction of malignancies. During the destruction of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells, the release of intracellular electrolytes causes the following effects:

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Dehydration

questions.text: Which of the following is an autosomal recessive renal cystic disease?
questions.solution:
Nephronophthisis is an autosomal recessive renal cystic disease.

It belongs to a category of conditions called ciliopathies. It occurs due to an underlying defect in the primary cilia of the tubular epithelial cells. The cilia play an important role in cell signaling and maintenance of cell growth, proliferation, and secretion.

Other ciliopathies include autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease, and medullary cystic kidney disease. 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Wide splitting of S2 may be seen in all except
questions.solution: Delayed P2 is seen in Pulmonary embolism leading to wide splitting.

questions.text: Adrenal pheochromocytoma predominantly secretes
questions.solution:
Adrenal pheochromocytoma predominantly secretes Norepinephrine. 

In extra adrenal pheochromocytoma, norepinephrine is exclusively secreted.

Note:

Pheochromocytomas in the VHL syndrome is characterized by a noradrenergic biochemical phenotype, whereas in contrast to the general, those in patients with MEN 2 are characterized by an adrenergic phenotype.

Malignant pheochromocytoma secretes epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine.

Pheochromocytomas roughly follow the 10% rule:

  • 10% malignant
  • 10% extra-adrenal
  • 10% bilateral

Headache, palpitation and diaphoresis is the classic triad of pheochromocytomas. The presence of all three manifestations in association with hypertension makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis

Symptoms can be precipitated by stress, exercise, surgery, drugs like beta-blockers and IV contrast agents

24 - hour urinary tests for metanephrines (total or fractionated) and catecholamines are commonly used for initial biochemical evaluation. Measuring Plasma fractionated metanephrines is the first-line test when there is a high index of suspicion.

For localization of the tumour, contrast CT/MRI and MIBG scintigraphy is used.

Pheochromocytomas are highly vascular tumors and hence FNAC is not done in them.

Treatment of Pheochromocytomas:

  • Alpha-blocker alone or Alpha + Beta-blocker.
  • Surgery is done to remove the tumour.

questions.text: A 20 year old adolescent girl complains of recurrent occipital headache with associated vertigo, tinnitus, difficulty in hearing, diplopia. There are symptom free intervals between the episodes. There is history of similar complaints in her mother too. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Migraine is an episodic headache associated with features like sensitivity to light , sound or movement. Nausea and vomiting often accompany the headache. Patient may have aura (classical migraine) or may not have aura (common migraine).

Types of migraine:

  • Focal migraine: transient dysphagia , hemisensory symptoms associated with migraine.
  • Migraine sine migraine: episodic visual disturbance without headache, common in elderly.
  • Retinal migraine: acute transient unilateral loss of vision.
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine: recurrent transient 3rd nerve palsy which begins after headache. 
  • Familial hemiplegic migraine: failure of recovery of focal neurological features after an attack of migraine.
  • Basilar migraine: occurs in children, aura associated with numbness and tingling of lips and extremities

questions.text: Most common cause of stroke in young women in India among OCP users
questions.solution:
Venous sinus thrombosis of the lateral or sagittal sinus or of small cortical veins (cortical vein thrombosis) occurs as a complication of: 

  • oral contraceptive use,
  • pregnancy and the postpartum period,
  • inflammatory bowel disease,
  • intracranial infections (meningitis),
  • dehydration.

Women who take oral contraceptives may be at particularly high risk for sinus thrombosis, patients present with a headache and may also have focal neurologic signs (especially paraparesis) and seizures.

Often, CT imaging is normal unless an intracranial venous hemorrhage has occurred, but the venous sinus occlusion is readily visualized using magnetic resonance (MR) or CT venography or conventional x-ray angiography.

questions.text: A 32-year-old businessman came to you with acute abdominal pain radiating to the tip of the penis. A diagnosis of calcium monohydrate kidney stone is made. The shape of this urine crystal on microscopy would be
questions.solution:
Dumbbell shaped stones are seen in Calcium Monohydrate kidney stones.

Crystal Appereance on Urine Microscopy
Calcium oxalate monohydrate Dumbbell or hourglass
Calcium oxalate dihydrate Enveloped or bipyramidal
Calcium phosphate (apatite) Amorphous
Brushite Needle shaped
Struvite Coffin lid
Uric acid Multifaceted, irregular plates of rossettes
Cystine Hexagonal or benzene rings

questions.text: The wave abnormality marked by arrow in the given ECG will be seen in which condition
questions.solution:
The wave seen in the given ECG is Osborn wave.

Systemic hypothermia  prolongs repolarization,  usually with a distinctive convex elevation of the J point  called as the Osborn wave.

Osborn wave:

  • Camel-hump sign
  • Late delta wave
  • Hathook junction
  • Hypothermic wave
  • Prominent J wave
  • K wave
  • H wave
  • Current of injury

questions.text: What is the size of pore of the glomerular membrane?
questions.solution:
The pores of the glomerular membrane are thought to be about 8 nanometers (80 angstroms).

The filtration membrane

  It consists of 3 parts  

  • Endothelium of glomerulus with  
  • Basal Lamina / Basement Membrane of Glomerulus GBM 
  • Slit membrane between pedicels of Podocyte

 

Important note  

  • The molecular diameter of albumin is only about 6 nanometers and it has a negative charge 
  • Still not filtered because GBM also has a Negative charge 
  • Both Repel each other

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Early loss of procedural memory is not a feature of Alzheimer's disease.

Alzheimer's disease is a syndrome of acquired global or multifocal impairment of cognitive function involving a decline of intellect, memory, or personality in the presence of normal consciousness.

Risk factors:

  • Old age
  • ApoE ε4 allele
  • Less education
  • Diabetes
  • Positive family history
  • Head trauma 
  • Female sex
  • Viruses, prion

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to result as a complication of CKD?
questions.solution:
Chronic kidney disease is typically associated with anemia due to associated low erythropoietin levels, not polycythemia.

Complications of declining kidney function include:

  • Volume overload
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Mineral and bone disorders
  • Hypertension
  • Anemia
  • Dyslipidemia

CKD is a spectrum of pathophysiological processes resulting in abnormal kidney function, with a progressive decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). According to the Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcome (KDIGO) classification, CKD can be stratified using both GFR and albuminuria to predict the risk of progression of CKD:

Stages of CKD based on GFR (mL/min/1.73 m2):

Stage GFR  Description
G1 ≥90 Normal or high
G2 60-89 Mildly decreased
G3a 45-59

Mildly to moderately decreased
G3b 30-44 Moderately to severely decreased
G4 15-29 Severely decreased
G5 <15 Kidney failure

Stages of CKD based on albuminuria (mg/g):

Stage Albuminuria Description
A1 <30 Normal to mildly increased
A2 30-300 Moderately increased
A3 >300 Severely increased

 

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: Anti Hypertensive drugs used in hypertensive emergencies are all except?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine, when used will lower the BP but it can also cause tachycardia which can precipitate coronary ischemia, so it cannot be used for hypertensive emergency.

Hypertensive emergency:

Malignant Hypertension, is a severe hypertension with acute irreversible impairment of one or more organ systems.

Features:

  • High BP
  • Papilledema
  • Proteinuria
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Encephalopathy
  • Fibrinoid necrosis

Complications:

  • Acute renal failure
  • Heart failure
  • Coronary Artery disease
  • Encephalopathy

Drugs used in hypertensive emergency:

  • Nitroprusside
  • Nicardipine
  • Labetalol
  • Hydralazine
  • Esmolol
  • Nitroglycerine
  • Phentolamine
  • Fenoldopam

questions.text: Urine/plasma creatinine levels of <20 are observed in
questions.solution:
Urine/plasma creatinine ratio of <20 is observed in  Rhabdomyolysis which causes an intrinsic Renal AKI (acute tubular necrosis)

The other options are causes of prerenal AKI, in prerenal AKI, the urine/plasma creatinine is >40.

questions.text: Low CSF protein is seen in all except
questions.solution:
• In hypothyroidism there is high CSF levels.
  • In hypothyroidism , elevated CSF protein has been well documented in patients with isolated hypothyroidism and autoimmune thyroiditis associated encephalopathy. Researchers postulate this is due to dysfunction of BBB and protein exchange.

Other options:

  • Option a: In infants they tend to have low levels of CSF protein.
  • Option b: In patients who undergo recurrent LP, the protein levels are said to be low.
  • Option d: In pseudotumorcerebri the CSF protein is normal to low.

questions.text: All are true about Tako-Tsubo cardiomyopathy except

choices.text: Beta blocker is used in treatment

questions.solution:
Tako Tsubo Cardiomyopathy is more common in elderly women.

Tako Tsubo Cardiomyopathy:

  • It is also called as apical ballooning syndrome or stress-induced cardiomyopathy.
  • It occurs typically in older women after sudden intense emotional or physical stress.
  • The ventricle shows global ventricular dilation with basal contraction, forming the shape of the narrow-necked jar (takotsubo).

Present as:

  • Pulmonary edema
  • Hypotension
  • Chest pain
  • ECG changes- mimics an acute infarction.
  • The left ventricular dysfunction extends beyond a specific coronary artery distribution.
  • It generally resolves within days to weeks.

This acute cardiomyopathy may result from:

  • Intense sympathetic activation with heterogeneity of myocardial autonomic innervations.
  • Diffuse micro-vascular spasm.
  • Direct catecholamine toxicity.


Treatment:

  • Nitrates for pulmonary edema.
  • Intraaortic balloon pump if needed for low output.
  • Combined alpha and beta blockers rather than selective beta blockade if hemodynamically stable.
  • Magnesium for arrhythmias related to QT prolongation Anticoagulation is generally withheld due to the occasional occurrence of ventricular rupture.

Prognosis- good

Recurrences are common.

questions.text: In medically intractable epilepsy, which of the following modes of treatment provide highest rate of seizure freedom
questions.solution:
In approximately 1/3 of patients with epilepsy, seizures persist despite adequate trials of several antiepileptic drugs (AEDs). Surgery can provide seizure freedom for some patients with seizures resistant to AEDs.

A candidate for epilepsy surgery must have not attained acceptable seizure control with sufficient trials of AEDs and must have a reasonable chance of benefiting from surgery.

Surgical techniques:

  • Anteromedial temporal resection (AMTR): This is the most commonly performed procedure, with the clearest indications and best results.
  • Corpus callosotomy 
  • Multiple subpial transections (MST)
  • Functional hemispherectomy

Postoperative complications that may occur include the following:

  • AMTR – Hemiparesis, visual field deficit, infections, cranial nerve palsy, fever, verbal deficits and memory problems.
  • Corpus callosotomy – Hydrocephalus, aseptic meningitis, bleeding from the superior sagittal sinus, frontal lobe edema, venous infarction, and air embolism.
  • Functional hemispherectomy – Hemogenic meningitis, ventriculitis, cerebrospinal fluid leakage, and hydrocephalus; less commonly, stroke, infection, coma, and postoperative hemorrhage.

questions.text: Significant weight loss is
questions.solution:
Clinically significant weight loss is defined as the loss of 10 pounds (4.5 kg) or >5% of one's body weight over a period of 6-12 months.

Significant weight loss is associated with increased mortality, which can range from 9% to as high as 38% within 1 to 2.5 years in the absence of clinical awareness and attention.

questions.text: Infraclavicular lesion of TB is called as
questions.solution:
Lesions in TB include:

  • Ghons focus - Beneath the pleura in the basal segment of the upper or apical segment of lower lobe.
  • Ghon complex - Ghon focus+ Involvement of regional lymph node.
  • Ghon lesions - Calcified healed primary TB lesions.
  • Ranke's complex - I/L calcified hilar lymphadenopathy with Ghon lesions.
  • Simon's focus - Apical scarring with appearance of fibronodular patch.
  • Puhl's lesion - Lesion at apex of lung in chronic TB.
  • Assmann focus - Infraclavicular lesion.
  • Rich focus - TB calcified foci in brain, meninges and spinal cord.

questions.text: All are features of Pseudotumour cerebri except
questions.solution:
Benign Intracranial Hypertension/ Pseudotumour cerebri/ Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension.

Patient will have features of raised ICP (headache and papilledema). It occurs commonly in obese women (30-45 years of age)

With common complaints of blurring of vision, 6th nerve palsy but no altered sensorium.

Causes:

  • High dose of vitamin A,
  • quinolones,
  • withdrawal of corticosteroid therapy,
  • addison's disease,
  • hypoparathyroidism.

Characteristic features

  • High ICP, normal/small sized ventricles,
  • no focal neurological signs, (hence no convulsions)
  • papilledema (enlarged blind spot in the visual field),
  • normal CSF findings,
  • normal CT, MRI, Isotope brain scan, excessively slow wave activity on EEG but no seizure.

It is a benign self limiting disorder with favorable outcome.

Treatment:

  • Weight loss
  • Acetazolamide
  • Optic sheath fenestration
  • Lumbo-peritoneal shunt

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match

choices.text: Durozirz’s sign – Femoral diastolic murmur as blood flows backwards in diastole
Traube’s sign – capillary pulsations in nail bed

questions.solution:
Traube's sign – Pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Peripheral signs of Aortic Regurgitation:

  • Corrigan's sign - Carotid pulsation.
  • De Musset’s sign- Head nodding.
  • Duroziez’s sign – Femoral diastolic murmur as blood flows backwards in diastole.
  • Traube’s sign – Pistol shot sound over femoral arteries.
  • Quincke’s sign – Capillary pulsations in nail beds.
  • Hill’s sign – Lower limb BP is much higher than the upper limb.

questions.text: Most common benign tumour of heart is
questions.solution:
Myxoma:

  • It is the most common benign tumour of heart.
  • MC site- Left atrium.
  • Features may mimic mitral stenosis or Infective endocarditis.
  • Tumour plop may be heard.
  • No distant metastasis.
  • Investigations: Echocardiography.
  • Treatment: Excision.
  • Recurrence may occur.

questions.text: What is Brescia cimino fistula

choices.text: Cephalic vein anastomosed to radial artery
Cephalic vein anastomosed to ulnar artery
Median cubital vein anastomosed to radial artery
Median cubital vein anastomosed to ulnar artery

questions.solution:
The BresciaCimino fistula is a fistula in which the cephalic vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the radial artery. This results in arterialization of the vein. Areterialisation of the vein facilitates its subsequent use in the placement of large needles (typically 15 gauge) to access the circulation.

The most common complication of a fistula is thrombosis.

questions.text: All are complications of bronchiectasis except
questions.solution:
Bronchiectasis is not a premalignant condition, so Bronchogenic carcinoma is not a compication of Bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis:

  • Chronic infection of the bronchi and bronchioles leading to permanent dilatation of airways.

Pathogenesis: Vicious cycle hypothesis.

Organisms:

  • H. influenza.
  • P. aeruginosa
  • Bordetella pertussis.
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia.
  • Staph aureus.

Complications:

  • Pneumonia
  • Pleural effusion
  • Pneumothorax
  • Hemoptysis
  • Cerebral abscess
  • Amyloidosis
  • Lung abscess
  • Emphysema

Kartagener syndrome:

  • Sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Situs inversus
  • Infertility

Diagnosis:

  • Sputum culture
  • X ray chest: Tram track appearance and ring shadows
  • HRCT chest - IOC
  • Spirometry - obstructive pattern

Treatment:

  • Postural drainage
  • Chest physiotherapy
  • Antibiotic therapy
  • Bronchodilators
  • Surgery

 

              Site                           Causes
Upper lung field
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Postradiation fibrosis
Lower lung field
  • Chronic recurrent aspiration (scleroderma)
  • End stage fibrotic lung disease (traction bronchiectasis   from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis)
  • recurrent immunodeficiency-associated infections 
       (hypogammaglobulinemia)
Mid lung field
  • MAC infection
  • Immotile cilia syndrome
Central airways
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis(ABPA)
  • Mounier-Kuhn syndrome
  • Williams-Campbell syndrome

questions.text: In type II respiratory failure, there is
questions.solution:
Management of Respiratory failure:

  • Type I: - High flow Oxygen. (8 to 10 lit/ml).
  • Type II: - Low flow oxygen. (2 to 3 lit/ml).

Related Pearl: Types of Respiratory Failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure

Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology.

Low pO2

Normal/ low pCO2

High (pAO2-paO2)

Sepsis

Gastric aspiration

Pneumonia

Near-drowning

Multiple blood transfusions

Pancreatitis
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.

Low pO2

High pCO2

Normal (pAO2-paO2)

Drug overdose

Brainstem injury

Sleep-disordered breathing

Severe hypothyroidism

Myasthenia gravis

Guillain-Barre syndrome

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

 

pO2- partial pressure of oxygen

pCO2- partial pressure of carbon dioxide

(pAO2-paO2)- alveolar- arterial oxygen gradient

questions.text: Mc Connell sign is seen in
questions.solution:
The best-known indirect sign of Pulmonary Embolism on transthoracic echocardiography is McConnell's sign.

Mc Connell’s sign:  Hypokinesis of the RV free wall with normal or hyperkinetic motion of the RV apex.

Chest X-ray in the case of pulmonary embolism:

  • West-mark sign: Focal oligemia of affected segment.
  • Pallas sign: Dilated right descending pulmonary artery.
  • Hamptons Hump: wedge shaped opacities above the diaphragm

ECG:

  • Sinus tachycardia.
  • SIQIIITIII  pattern.

Blood test: D- dimer assay-  The best screening test.

questions.text: The most common cause of infection after 6 months of renal transplant is
questions.solution:
Among the given options, most common cause of infection after 6 months of transplant is BK virus. 

The most common Opportunistic Infections in Renal Transplant Recipients: 

Peritansplant (less than 1 month) Early (1-6 months) Late (more than 6 months)
Wound infection Pneumocystis jiroveci Aspergillus
Herpes virus Cytomegalovirus Nocardia
Oral candiasis Legionella BK Virus (polyoma)
Urinary tract infection Listeria Herpes Zoster
  Hepatitis A Hepatitis B
  Hepatitis B Hepatitis C
  Hepatitis C

questions.text: All are causes of exudative pleural effusion except
questions.solution:
Cirrhosis causes transudative pleural effusion.

Exudative pleural effusion- protein concentration >3 gm%.

  • Transudative and exudative pleural effusions are distinguished by measuring the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and protein levels in the pleural fluid.
  • Exudative pleural effusions meet at least one of the following criteria, whereas transudative pleural effusions meet none.

The criteria include:

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5.
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6.
  • Pleural fluid LDH >2/3 of the normal upper limit for serum LDH.
                     Exudate              Transudate
  • Neoplastic diseases 
  • Infectious diseases 
  • Pulmonary embolization 
  • Gastrointestinal disease 
  • Collagen vascular diseases 
  • Post-coronary artery bypass surgery 
  • Asbestos exposure
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Uremia 
  • Meig's syndrome 
  • Yellow nail syndrome 
  • Drug-induced pleural disease 
  • Trapped lung 
  • Radiation therapy 
  • Post-cardiac injury syndrome 
  • Hemothorax 
  • Iatrogenic injury 
  • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome
  • Pericardial disease 
  • Chylo-thorax
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction
  • Myxedema
  • Urinothorax

questions.text: A postoperative cardiac surgical patient developed sudden hypotension, raised central venous pressure,  pulsus paradoxus at the 4th post operative hour. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The case is that of Cardiac tamponade as the patient has sudden Low BP and pulsus paradoxus.

Cardiac tamponade:

Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space raises the intra pericardial pressure, hence poor ventricular filling and fall in cardiac output.

It is characterized by:

  • Hypotension.
  • Pulsus paradoxus.
  • Increased pulse rate.
  • Prominent X descent.
  • Muffled heart sound.
  • Ewart’s sign (bronchial breathing at left angle of scapula).
  • Beck’s triad: Falling BP, Raised JVP, Small quiet heart.

Investigation:

  • X-ray chest - Big globular heart.
  • ECG - Low voltage, Electrical alternans.
  • ECHO - Echo free zone around the heart.
  • Cath - Diastolic collapse of right atrium and right ventricle.

Treatment: Drainage of fluid

questions.text: Sleep apnea is defined as temporary pause in  breathing during sleep for atleast
questions.solution:
Sleep apnea is defined as temporary pause in breathing during sleep for at least 10 seconds.

Sleep apnoea may be:

  • Central.
  • Obstructive.

Features:

  • Obese.
  • Snoring.
  • Daytime somnolence.

Complications:

  • Pulmonary hypertension.
  • Type II respiratory failure.

Investigations- Polysomnography (PSG)

Management:

  • Weight reduction.
  • CPAP via a nasal mask during sleep.

Apnea - An apnea is the cessation, or near cessation, of airflow. Scoring an apnea on PSG requires documentation of a 90 percent or greater decrease in airflow, compared with preceding signals, for a minimum of 10 seconds

Hypopneas — Hypopnea is a reduction of airflow to a degree that is insufficient to meet the criteria for an apnea

Respiratory effort-related arousals — Respiratory effort-related arousals (RERAs) are arousals that are associated with a change in airflow that does not meet the criteria for apnea or hypopnea

In addition to a report of the total number of apneas, hypopneas, and respiratory effort-related arousals (RERAs), PSG reports typically contain a number of other variables derived from these and other data.

  • AHI (Apnoea Hypopnoea Index)= No. of apnea + No. of hypopnoea/ hour of sleep.
  • RDI(Respiratory Disturbance Index)= No. of apnea + No. of hypopnea + No. of RERAs / hours of sleep.
OSAHS grade No.of AHI events/hr
Mild 5-14
Moderate 15-29
Severe ≥30

questions.text: In small cell carcinoma all of the hormone levels given will be increased except
questions.solution:
Paraneoplastic syndromes are common in patients with lung cancer, especially those with SCLC, and may be the presenting finding or the first sign of recurrence.

Hormones produced by Small cell lung cancer include:

  • ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone)
  • ANP (Atrial natriuretic peptide or atrial natriuretic factor - ANF)
  • ADH (Antidiuretic hormone  or Arginine vasopressin - AVP)
  • Gonadotropins
  • Calcitonin

Small cell lung cancer:

  • Previously called as Oat cell lung cancer.
  • Usually present with central masses.
  • Associated with cigarette smoking.
  • Causes hypokalemia and hypocalcemia.
  • Highly malignant and metastatic lung cancer.
  • Treatment: Chemotherapy with or without radiotherapy.

questions.text: Normal O2 tension with reduced O2 carrying capacity of blood is seen in which type of hypoxia
questions.solution:
Anemic hypoxia:

Hypoxia in which the Arterial PO2 is normal but the O2 carrying capacity of blood is reduced.

Causes:

  • Blood loss.
  • Abnormal hemoglobin (Sickle cell anemia, MetHb).
  • Carbon monoxide poisoning.
